tit.cmt: 以下人名等の読み方については、ブリタニカ国際大百科事典、広辞苑 kotobank.jpで確認、

sen.j: 有栖川宮（ありすがわのみや）は、かつて存在した宮家の一つ。
sen.e: ARISUGAWA no miya is the name of the court noble // princely house existed a long time ago.
sen.cmt: 宮家 定訳不明宮家 court noble // princely house 英辞郎ON the WEB
sen.e: ARISUGAWA no miya was the name of the court noble, princely house that existed a long time ago.
Arisugawa no miya was the name of the Miyake (house of an imperial prince) that existed long ago.
sen.cmt: "ARISUGAWA→Arisugawacourt noble (princely house)"→"Miyake (house of an imperial prince) "に変更しました。

sen.j: 伏見宮、桂宮、閑院宮とともに四世襲親王家という。
sen.e: ARISUGAWA no miya was called one of the four biggest hereditary Imperial Prince's Family along with FUSHIMI no miya, KATSURA no miya and KAN-IN no miya.
sen.cmt: 親王家 定訳不明伏見宮 Fushimi no miya, 桂宮 Katsura no miya, Kan-in no miya 閑院宮, 親王家 Imperial Prince's Family 研究社新和英大辞典
sen.e: ARISUGAWA no miya was called one of the four biggest hereditary Imperial Prince's families, along with FUSHIMI no miya, KATSURA no miya and KAN-IN no miya.
Arisugawa no miya was called one of the four biggest hereditary Imperial Prince's families, along with Fushimi no miya, Katsura no miya and Kan-in no miya.

sen.j: 宮号の由来は、伏見宮家の祖、栄仁親王が、有栖川とも称したことに因む。
sen.e: The name of ARISUGAWA came from Prince Yoshihito, the originator of FUSHIMI no miya, as his name was also called ARISUGAWA.
The name of ARISUGAWA came from Prince Yoshihito, the originator of FUSHIMI no miya, since his name was also ARISUGAWA.
The name of Arisugawa came from Prince Yoshihito, the originator of Fushimi no miya, since his name was also Arisugawa.

sen.j: 第二代良仁親王が、即位し、後西天皇となった。
sen.e: The second Prince Nagahito enthroned and became Emperor GO-SAI.
sen.cmt: 良仁親王 Prince Nagahito, 後西天皇 Emperor GO-SAI 研究社新和英大辞典
sen.e: The second Prince Nagahito was enthroned and became Emperor GO-SAI.
The second prince, Nagahito, was enthroned and became Emperor Go-Sai.

sen.j: 概要
sen.e: Overview
Overview
Summary

sen.j: 有栖川宮家は歴代、書道・歌道の師範を勤めて皇室の信任篤く、将軍家とも婚姻関係を結び、公武ともに密接であった。
sen.e: ARISUGAWA no miya used to teach calligraphy, poem over the generations and had a trust from Imperial Families, also had a close relationship with Shogun families as there was marriage relationship between them, they were close to both court nobles and Samurai families.

ARISUGAWA no miya had taught calligraphy and poetry to succeeding generations and had the trust of the Imperial Family; additionally, he had a close relationship with Shogun families as there was a marriage relationship between them and they were close to both court nobles and samurai families.

Arisugawa no miya had taught calligraphy and poetry to succeeding generations and had the trust of the Imperial Family; additionally, he had a close relationship with shogun families as there was a marriage relationship between them and they were close to both court nobles and samurai families.

sen.j: また代々、江戸上野の寛永寺や京都東山の知恩院などに次男以下の子弟を門跡として入寺させていた。
sen.e: For generations the ARISUGAWA no miya used to send sons of the family, except for the eldest son, to Kan-ei-ji Temple in Ueno, Edo and Chion-in Temple in Higashiyama, Kyoto as an Imperial prince in holy orders; a priest-prince.
sen.cmt: 門跡 an Imperial prince in holy orders; a priest-prince 定訳不明江戸上野の寛永寺 Kan-ei-ji Temple in Ueno, Edo, 知恩院 Chion-in Temple in Higashiyama, Kyoto, 門跡 an Imperial prince in holy orders; a priest-prince 研究社新和英大辞典 定訳不明
sen.e: For generations the ARISUGAWA no miya used to send sons of the family, except for the eldest son, to Kan-ei-ji Temple in Ueno, Edo and to Chion-in Temple in Higashiyama, Kyoto as an Imperial prince in holy orders, or a so-called priest-prince.

For generations the Arisugawa no miya used to send sons of the family, except for the eldest son, to Kan-ei-ji Temple in Ueno, Edo and to Chion-in Temple in Higashiyama, Kyoto, as imperial princes in holy orders, or so-called priest-princes.

sen.j: 寛永2年（1625年）、後陽成天皇の第7皇子・高松宮好仁親王が創設。
sen.e: In 1625, the Emperor GO-YOZEI's 7th Prince, PrinceTAKAMATSU no miya Yoshihito established ARISUNOGAWA no miya.
sen.cmt: 後陽成天皇 the Emperor Go-Yozei, 高松宮好仁親王 Prince Takamatsu no miya Yoshihito
sen.e: In 1625, Emperor GO-YOZEI's seventh prince, TAKAMATSU no miya Yoshihito, established ARISUNOGAWA no miya.
In 1625, Emperor Go-Yozei's seventh prince, Takamatsu no miya Yoshihito, established Arisugawa no miya.

sen.j: 宮号は、初め高松宮で、親王の祖母・勧修寺晴子の御所高松殿に由来する。
sen.e: The name of the court noble started from TAKAMATSU no miya and then originated his grandmother, Haruko KANSHUJI's palace,Takamatsu-Dono.
sen.cmt: 勧修寺晴子 Haruko KANSHUJI, 御所高松殿 Takamatsu-Dono
sen.e: The name of the court noble started from TAKAMATSU no miya and then established Takamatsu-Dono, the palace of his grandmother, Haruko KANSHUJI.
The name of the court noble started with Takamatsu no miya and then established Takamatsu-Dono, the palace of his grandmother, Haruko KANSHUJI.

sen.j: 好仁親王は征夷大将軍 徳川秀忠の養女・亀姫（実父は秀忠の甥で娘婿にも当たる越前藩松平忠直）を妃としたが嗣子が無かったため、甥にあたる後水尾天皇の皇子・良仁親王が養嗣子として第2代となり、花町宮を名乗った。
sen.e: Prince Yoshihito's Empress was Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo, Hidetada TOKUGAWA's adopted daughter, Kame-Hime, Princess Kame, (her real father was Hidetada's nephew and son in law, Tadao MATSUDAIRA of Echizen han, Echizen domain), they did not have any male child, so their nephew, Prince Nagahito, Emperor GO-MIZUNOO's Prince was adopted to become 2nd generation of the court noble, he named HANAMACHI no miya.
sen.cmt: 征夷大将軍, 越前藩 定訳不明好仁親王Prince Yoshihito, 征夷大将軍 Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo 英辞郎ON the WEB, 徳川秀忠 Hidetada TOKUGAWA, 亀姫Kame-Hime, Princess Kame, 越前藩 the Echizen han; the Echizen domain 研究社新和英大辞典, 松平忠直 Tadanao MATSUDAIRA, 後水尾天皇 the Emperor Go-Mizunoo, 花町宮 Hanamachi no miya
sen.e: Prince Yoshihito's Empress was the barbarian subduing generalissimo, Hidetada TOKUGAWA's adopted daughter, Kame-Hime (Princess Kame) (her real father was Hidetada's nephew and son-in-law, Tadao MATSUDAIRA of Echizen han, Echizen domain); but they did not have a male child, so their nephew, Prince Nagahito, Emperor GO-MIZUNOO's prince was adopted to become the second generation of the court nobility, being so name HANAMACHI no miya.

Prince Yoshihito's Empress was Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), Hidetada TOKUGAWA's adopted daughter, Kame-Hime (Princess Kame) (her real father was Hidetada's nephew and son-in-law, Tadao MATSUDAIRA of Echizen han, Echizen domain); but they did not have a male child, so their nephew, Prince Nagahito, Emperor Mizunoo's prince, was adopted to become the second generation of the court nobility, being so named Hanamachi no miya.
sen.cmt: GO-MIZUNOO→Go-MizunooHANAMACHI→Hanamachi"the barbarian subduing generalissimo"→"Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians")"に変更しました。

sen.j: やがて良仁親王が後西天皇として即位することになるが、これは先代後光明天皇の養子・識仁親王（後の霊元天皇）が幼少であったための中継ぎであり、後西天皇は自分の皇子・有栖川宮幸仁親王に高松宮を継がせて、宮号を有栖川宮（幸仁親王の別荘所在地である京都・有栖川に由来）に改めた。
sen.e: Since the former Emperor GO-KOMYO's adopted Prince, Prince Satohito (later called Emperor REIGEN) was too young to succeed the Imperial Throne, soon Prince Nagahito enthroned as Emperor GOSAI for a meantime, the Emperor ordered his Prince ARISUGAWA no miya Yukihito to take over TAKAMATSU no miya, his original name of court noble was change to ARISUGAWA no miya. (The name came from Prince Yoshihito's temporally palace in Arisugawa, Kyoto.)
sen.cmt: 後光明天皇 the Emperor Go-Komyo, 識仁親王 Prince Satoshito, 霊元天皇 Emperor REIGEN, 有栖川宮幸仁親王 Prince Arisugawa no miya Yukihito
sen.e: Since the former Emperor GO-KOMYO's adopted son, Prince Satohito (later called Emperor REIGEN) was too young to succeed the Imperial Throne, Prince Nagahito was soon enthroned as Emperor GOSAI for the meantime; the Emperor ordered his Prince ARISUGAWA no miya Yukihito to take over TAKAMATSU no miya, so that his original name of court noble was change to ARISUGAWA no miya (the name came from Prince Yoshihito's temporary palace in Arisugawa, Kyoto).

Since the former Emperor Go-Komyo's adopted son, Prince Satohito (later called Emperor Reigen) was too young to succeed to the Imperial Throne, Prince Nagahito was soon enthroned as Emperor Gosai for the meantime; the Emperor ordered his Prince Arisugawa no miya Yukihito to take over Takamatsu no miya so that his original name as a court noble was changed to Arisugawa no miya (the name came from Prince Yoshihito's temporary palace in Arisugawa, Kyoto).

sen.j: その後、幸仁親王の子・有栖川宮正仁親王が嗣子無く没したため、霊元天皇の皇子・有栖川宮職仁親王が入って第5代を継承し、以後、6代・有栖川宮織仁親王、7代・有栖川宮韶仁親王、8代・有栖川宮幟仁親王、9代・有栖川宮熾仁親王、10代・有栖川宮威仁親王と、いずれも直系を以って伝えたが、1913年（大正2年）1月5日、威仁親王の薨去によって実質的に断絶が確定し、1923年（大正12年）6月29日、威仁親王妃慰子の薨去によって正式に絶家となった。
sen.e: After that Prince TAKAMATSU's child, Prince ARISUGAWA no miya Tadahito died without having any children, Emperor RENGEN's Prince, Prince ARISUGAWA no miya Yorihito succeeded as the 5th court noble, then followed by 6th Prince ARISUGAWA no miya Orihito, 7th Prince ARISUGAWA no miya Tsunahito, 8th Prince ARISUGAWA no miya Takahito, 9th Prince ARISUGAWA no miya Taruhito, 10th Prince ARISUGAWA no miya Takehito, it was passed to within lineal relation, on January 5th, 1913 after Prince Takehito died, it was definite that there was no successor to take over the family, on 29th June 1923, the family name officially died after Princess Yasuko (Prince Takehito's wife) passed away.
sen.cmt: 韶仁親王 読み不明 正仁親王 Prince Tadahito, 職仁親王Prince Yorihito, 宮織仁親王 Prince Orihito, 韶仁親王 Tsunahito, 幟仁親王 Prince Takahito, 熾仁親王 Prince Taruhito, 威仁親王 Prince Takehito,威仁親王妃慰子,Princess Yasuko (Prince Takehito's wife) 定訳不明
sen.e: Subsequently, Prince TAKAMATSU's child, Prince ARISUGAWA no miya Tadahito, died without having any children, Emperor RENGEN's Prince, Prince ARISUGAWA no miya Yorihito succeeded as the fifth court noble, followed by the sixth Prince ARISUGAWA no miya Orihito, the seventh Prince ARISUGAWA no miya Tsunahito, the eighth Prince ARISUGAWA no miya Takahito, the ninth Prince ARISUGAWA no miya Taruhito and the tenth Prince ARISUGAWA no miya Takehito, it was passed down through the lineage; however, on January 5, 1913 after Prince Takehito died, it was definite that there was no successor to take over the family, so on June 29, 1923, the family name officially died after Princess Yasuko (Prince Takehito's wife) passed away.

Subsequently, Prince Yoshihito's child, Prince Arisugawa no miya Tadahito, died without having any children, Emperor Reigen's Prince Arisugawa no miya Yorihito succeeded as the fifth court noble, followed by the sixth prince, Arisugawa no miya Orihito; the seventh prince, Arisugawa no miya Tsunahito; the eighth prince, Arisugawa no miya Takahito; the ninth prince, Arisugawa no miya Taruhito; and the tenth prince, Arisugawa no miya Takehito, it was passed down through the lineage; however, on January 5, 1913, after the death of Prince Takehito, it was definite that there was no successor to take over the family, so on June 29, 1923, the family name officially died after Princess Yasuko (Prince Takehito's wife) passed away.

sen.j: しかし祭祀は、大正天皇の第三子により継承され、宮号は、その際、ふたたび高松宮と改められた。
sen.e: However the event was handed down by the third child of Emperor TAISHO and the name of the court noble was re-named to TAKAMATSU no miya.
However, the event was handed down by the third child of Emperor TAISHO and the name of the court noble was changed to TAKAMATSU no miya.
However, the event was handed down by the third child of Emperor Taisho and the name of the court noble was changed to Takamatsu no miya.

sen.j: 賀茂季鷹・岸駒・飯田忠彦など、著名な文化人や学者を家臣として抱えていたことも有名。
sen.e: It is well known they had famous highly educated people as their retainer such as KAMO no Suetaka, Ganku and Tadahiko IIDA.
sen.cmt: 賀茂季鷹 KAMO no Suetaka, 岸駒 Ganku, 飯田忠彦 Tadahiko IIDA
sen.e: It is well known they had famous, highly educated people as retainers, such as KAMO no Suetaka, Ganku and Tadahiko IIDA.
It is well known they had famous, highly educated people as retainers, such as KAMO no Suetaka, Ganku and Tadahiko IIDA.

sen.j: 3代・幸仁親王は、延宝8年（1680年）に将軍家綱が死去した際、大老の酒井忠清によって将軍に擁立されようとした、とする宮将軍擁立説がある。
sen.e: There is an episode when Shogun Ietsuna died in 1680, the 3rd successor, Prince Yukihito was about to be captured by a Chief Minister, Tadakiyo SAKAI, it is one of the theory known as both Imperial Palace and Shogun tried to set up the story.
sen.cmt: 大老 a chief minister 研究社新和英大辞典, 酒井忠清 Tadakiyo SAKAI
sen.e: There is an episode in which, when Shogun Ietsuna died in 1680, the third successor, Prince Yukihito, was about to be captured by a chief minister, Tadakiyo SAKAI; it is one of the theories that emerged and became known, as both the Imperial Palace and Shogun tried to set up the story.

There is an episode in which, when Shogun Ietsuna died in 1680, the third successor, Prince Yukihito, was about to be captured by a chief minister, Tadakiyo SAKAI; it is one of the theories that emerged and became known, as both the Imperial Palace and Shogun tried to set up the story.

sen.j: 6代・織仁親王の娘のうち、楽宮喬子女王は12代将軍 徳川家慶の正室となり、登美宮吉子女王は徳川斉昭の正室となって徳川慶喜を生んだ。
sen.e: One of the 6th successor, Prince Orihito's daughter, Princess Sazanomiya Takako became wife of 12th Shogun, Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA and Princess Tomi no miya Yoshiko became wife of Nariaki TOKUGAWA and had Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA.
sen.cmt: 楽宮喬子女王 Princess Sazanomiya Takako http://jiten.biglobe.ne.jp/j/72/d5/f9/b508586386a69dadb6872a3be20dec3b.htm, 徳川家慶 Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA, 登美宮吉子女王 Princess Tomi no miya Yoshiko, 徳川斉昭 Nariaki TOKUGAWA, 徳川慶喜 Yoshinobu TOKKUGAWA
sen.e: One of the sixth successors, Prince Orihito's daughter Princess Sazanomiya Takako, became the wife of the twelfth shogun, Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA; moreover, Princess Tomi no miya Yoshiko became the wife of Nariaki TOKUGAWA and had Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA.

One of the sixth successors, Prince Orihito's daughter Princess Sazanomiya Takako, became the wife of the twelfth shogun, Ieyoshi TOKUGAWA; moreover, Princess Tomi no miya Yoshiko became the wife of Nariaki TOKUGAWA and had Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 8代・幟仁親王（1812年-1886年）は、國學院大学の前身である皇典講究所や神道教導職の総裁に任ぜられ、明治天皇、和宮親子内親王の学問師範を務めた功績を以って大勲位菊花大綬章を賜った。
sen.e: 8th successor Prince Takahito was ordered to become a president of Koten Kokyu sho (former Kokugakuin University) and Shinto Kyodo shoku, after teaching various studies to Emperor MEIJI and Princess Kazuno miya Chikako, he was given the Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum for the recognition of his achievement as a teacher.
sen.cmt: 皇典講究所, 神道教導職 定訳不明皇典講究所 Koten Kokyu sho Kokugakuin University, 神道教導職 Shinto Kyodo shoku, 國學院大学 Kokugakuin University, 明治天皇 Emperor MEIJI, 和宮親子内親王 Princess Kazuno miya Chikako, 大勲位菊花大綬章 the Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum 研究社新和英大辞典
sen.e: The eighth successor, Prince Takahito, was ordered to become a president of Koten Kokyu sho (former Kokugakuin University) and Shinto Kyodo shoku; after teaching Emperor MEIJI and Princess Kazuno miya Chikako in various studies he was given the Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum in recognition of his achievements as a teacher.

The eighth successor, Prince Takahito (1812-1886), was ordered to become the president of Koten Kokyu sho (the former Kokugakuin University) and Shinto Kyodo shoku; after teaching Emperor Meiji and Princess Kazuno miya Chikako in various studies, he was given the Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum in recognition of his achievements as a teacher.

sen.j: また、有栖川流書道を大成させ、五箇条の御誓文の正本を揮毫した。
sen.e: Also ARISUGAWA style calligraphy was established and Prince Takahito wrote an original copy of the Imperial Covenant Consisting of Five Articles.
sen.cmt: 五箇条の御誓文 定訳不明五箇条の御誓文 the Imperial Covenant Consisting of Five Articles 研究社新和英大辞典
sen.e: Moreover, ARISUGAWA style calligraphy was established and Prince Takahito wrote an original copy of the "Imperial Covenant Consisting of Five Articles."
Moreover, Arisugawa style calligraphy was established and Prince Takahito wrote an original copy of the "Imperial Covenant Consisting of Five Articles."

sen.j: 9代・熾仁親王（1835年-1895年）は和宮の婚約者だった人として知られ、明治維新前後において軍人として活躍し、政治面でも元老院議官、次いで議長を務めた。
sen.e: 9th successor Prince Taruhito (1835-1895) was Princess Kazunomiya's fiancee, he played active part as a solider before and after the Meiji Restoration, also did well politically being a member of Chamber of Elders; the Senate and a Chairman.
sen.cmt: 明治維新 the Meiji Restoration 定訳不明, 元老院 the Chamber of Elders; the Senate 定訳不明
sen.e: The ninth successor, Prince Taruhito (1835-1895), was Princess Kazunomiya's fiancee, who was active as a solider before and after the Meiji Restoration; he also did well politically, serving as a member of the Chamber of Elders, a senator and a chairman.

The ninth successor, Prince Taruhito (1835-1895), was Princess Kazunomiya's fiancee, who was active as a solider before and after the Meiji Restoration; he also did well politically, serving as a member of the Chamber of Elders, a senator and a chairman.

sen.j: 熾仁親王は慶応3年（1867年）12月、王政復古により総裁の座に就き、戊辰戦争に際して東征軍大総督を務め、1877年（明治10年）の西南戦争で征討総督となり、1894年（明治27年）の日清戦争では陸海全軍の総参謀長を務めた。
sen.e: Prince Taruhito became President after the restoration of imperial rule in December 1867, also acted as Toigun Governor-General in the Boshin War, attack commander in the Seinan War;the Southwestern (Satsuma) Rebellion in 1877, and became Army and Navy Chief General at the Shino-Japanese War in 1894.
sen.cmt: 王政復古 the restoration of imperial rule 研究社新和英大辞典, 戊辰戦争 the Boshin Wat,西南戦争 the Seinan War;the Southwestern (Satsuma) Rebellion 研究社新和英大辞典, 日清戦争 the Sino-Japanese War 研究社新和英大辞典
sen.e: Prince Taruhito became the President after the restoration of Imperial rule in December 1867, but he also acted as Toigun Governor-General during the Boshin War, attack commander in the Seinan War (the Southwestern (Satsuma) Rebellion in 1877), and became Chief General of the Army and Navy in the Sino-Japanese War of 1894.

Prince Taruhito became the President after the restoration of Imperial rule in December 1867, but he also acted as Toigun Governor-General during the Boshin War, attack commander in the Seinan War (the Southwestern (Satsuma) Rebellion in 1877), and became Chief General of the Army and Navy in the Sino-Japanese War of 1894.

sen.j: 10代・威仁親王（1862年-1914年）は元帥・海軍大将となったほか、東宮時代の大正天皇をよく輔導した。
sen.e: 10th successor Prince Takehito (1862-1914) became a marshal and a full admiral, he helped Emperor TAISHO when he was still a Prince.
The tenth successor Prince Takehito (1862-1914) became a marshal and a full admiral; moreover, he assisted Emperor TAISHO when he was still a prince.
The tenth successor, Prince Takehito (1862-1914), became a marshal and a full admiral; moreover, he assisted Emperor Taisho when he was still a prince.

sen.j: 威仁親王の嗣子・栽仁王は父に先じて早世したが、有栖川宮3代の勲功に鑑み、大正天皇は親王の臨終に際し、特旨を以って第3皇子・高松宮宣仁親王に高松宮の称号を与え、有栖川宮家の祭祀を継がせた。
sen.e: Prince Takehito's adopted child, Prince Tanehito died before his father, but he put efforts to make 3rd generation of ARISUGAWA no miya, when the Prince died the Emperor TAISHO gave the name of TAKAMATSU no miya, as an exception, to the 3rd Prince, TAKAMATSU no miya Nobuhito to succeed ARISUNOGAWA no miya family events.
sen.cmt: 高松宮宣仁親王 Prince Takamatsu no miya Nobuhito
sen.e: Prince Takehito's adopted child, Prince Tanehito, died before his father, but he endeavored to make the third generation of ARISUGAWA no miya, and when the Prince died the Emperor TAISHO gave the name of TAKAMATSU no miya, as an exception, to the third prince, TAKAMATSU no miya Nobuhito, to succeed ARISUNOGAWA no miya in family events.

Prince Takehito's adopted child, Prince Tanehito, died before his father, but he endeavored to make the third generation of Arisugawa no miya, and when the Prince died the Emperor Taisho gave the name of Takamatsu no miya, as an exception, to the third prince, Takamatsu no miya Nobuhito, to succeed Arisugawa no miya in family events.

sen.j: なお宣仁親王妃となった宣仁親王妃喜久子は威仁親王の外孫である。
sen.e: The Prince Nobuhito's Empress, Princess Kikuko was a maternal grandchild of Prince Takehito.
The Prince Nobuhito's Empress, Princess Kikuko, was a maternal grandchild of Prince Takehito.
The Prince Nobuhito's Empress, Princess Kikuko, was a maternal grandchild of Prince Takehito.

sen.j: 有栖川宮詐欺事件
sen.e: ARISUGAWA no miya fraud incident
The ARISUGAWA no miya fraud incident
The Arisugawa no miya fraud incident

sen.j: 2003年（平成15年）、有栖川宮家の末裔（宣仁親王御落胤）と自称する者による詐欺事件が起きた。
sen.e: In 2003, a person named as descendant of ARISUGAWA no miya family (an illegitimate child of Prince Nobuhito) committed fraud.
In 2003, a person named as descendant of ARISUGAWA no miya family (an illegitimate child of Prince Nobuhito) committed fraud.
In 2003, a person named as a descendant of the Arisugawa no miya family (an illegitimate child of Prince Nobuhito) committed fraud.

sen.j: 詳細は有栖川宮詐欺事件を参照のこと。
sen.e: Please refer to the section of ARISUGAWA no miya fraud incident for the details.
For details, please refer to the section on the ARISUGAWA no miya fraud incident.
For details, please refer to the section on the Arisugawa no miya fraud incident.
